available.name: available
available.comment:
Returns true if the API is available. The common causes of an API not being avilable are:

  • a permission is missing in the application's manifest.json file
  • the API is defined on a newer version of Chrome then the current runtime

lastError.name: lastError
lastError.comment: This will be defined during an API method callback if there was an error

onBrowserUpdateAvailable.name: onBrowserUpdateAvailable
onBrowserUpdateAvailable.comment: Fired when a Chrome update is available, but isn't installed immediately because a browser restart is required.

onConnect.name: onConnect
onConnect.comment: Fired when a connection is made from either an extension process or a content script.

onConnectExternal.name: onConnectExternal
onConnectExternal.comment: Fired when a connection is made from another extension.

onInstalled.name: onInstalled
onInstalled.comment: Fired when the extension is first installed, when the extension is updated to a new version, and when Chrome is updated to a new version.

onMessage.name: onMessage
onMessage.comment: Fired when a message is sent from either an extension process or a content script.

onMessageExternal.name: onMessageExternal
onMessageExternal.comment: Fired when a message is sent from another extension/app. Cannot be used in a content script.

onRestartRequired.name: onRestartRequired
onRestartRequired.comment: Fired when an app or the device that it runs on needs to be restarted. The app should close all its windows at its earliest convenient time to let the restart to happen. If the app does nothing, a restart will be enforced after a 24-hour grace period has passed. Currently, this event is only fired for Chrome OS kiosk apps.

onStartup.name: onStartup
onStartup.comment: Fired when a profile that has this extension installed first starts up. This event is not fired when an incognito profile is started, even if this extension is operating in 'split' incognito mode.

onSuspend.name: onSuspend
onSuspend.comment: Sent to the event page just before it is unloaded. This gives the extension opportunity to do some clean up. Note that since the page is unloading, any asynchronous operations started while handling this event are not guaranteed to complete. If more activity for the event page occurs before it gets unloaded the onSuspendCanceled event will be sent and the page won't be unloaded.

onSuspendCanceled.name: onSuspendCanceled
onSuspendCanceled.comment: Sent after onSuspend to indicate that the app won't be unloaded after all.

onUpdateAvailable.name: onUpdateAvailable
onUpdateAvailable.comment: Fired when an update is available, but isn't installed immediately because the app is currently running. If you do nothing, the update will be installed the next time the background page gets unloaded, if you want it to be installed sooner you can explicitly call chrome.runtime.reload().

connect.name: connect
connect.comment:
Attempts to connect to other listeners within the extension/app (such as the background page), or other extensions/apps. This is useful for content scripts connecting to their extension processes. Note that this does not connect to any listeners in a content script. Extensions may connect to content scripts embedded in tabs via tabs.connect.

chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.connect.extensionId The ID of the extension/app you want to connect to. If omitted, default is your own extension.

Returns: Port through which messages can be sent and received. The port's [][runtime.Port onDisconnect] event is fired if the extension/app does not exist.

connectNative.name: connectNative
connectNative.comment:
Connects to a native application in the host machine.

chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.connectNative.application The name of the registered application to connect to.

Returns: Port through which messages can be sent and received with the application

getBackgroundPage.name: getBackgroundPage
getBackgroundPage.comment:
Retrieves the JavaScript 'window' object for the background page running inside the current extension/app. If the background page is an event page, the system will ensure it is loaded before calling the callback. If there is no background page, an error is set.

Returns: The JavaScript 'window' object for the background page.

getManifest.name: getManifest
getManifest.comment:
Returns details about the app or extension from the manifest. The object returned is a serialization of the full manifest file.

Returns: The manifest details.

getPackageDirectoryEntry.name: getPackageDirectoryEntry
getPackageDirectoryEntry.comment: Returns a DirectoryEntry for the package directory.

getURL.name: getURL
getURL.comment:
Converts a relative path within an app/extension install directory to a fully-qualified URL.

chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.getURL.path A path to a resource within an app/extension expressed relative to its install directory.

Returns: The fully-qualified URL to the resource.

requestUpdateCheck.name: requestUpdateCheck
requestUpdateCheck.comment:
Requests an update check for this app/extension.

Returns: status Result of the update check. enum of throttled, no_update, update_available details If an update is available, this contains more information about the available update.

restart.name: restart
restart.comment: Restart the ChromeOS device when the app runs in kiosk mode. Otherwise, it's no-op.

sendMessage.name: sendMessage
sendMessage.comment:
Sends a single message to onMessage event listeners within the extension (or another extension/app). Similar to chrome.runtime.connect, but only sends a single message with an optional response. The runtime.onMessage event is fired in each extension page of the extension. Note that extensions cannot send messages to content scripts using this method. To send messages to content scripts, use tabs.sendMessage.

chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.sendMessage.extensionId The extension ID of the extension you want to connect to. If omitted, default is your own extension.

Returns: The JSON response object sent by the handler of the message. If an error occurs while connecting to the extension, the callback will be called with no arguments and runtime.lastError will be set to the error message.

sendNativeMessage.name: sendNativeMessage
sendNativeMessage.comment:
Send a single message to a native application.

chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.sendNativeMessage.application The name of the native messaging host.

chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.sendNativeMessage.message The message that will be passed to the native messaging host.

Returns: The response message send by the native messaging host. If an error occurs while connecting to the native messaging host, the callback will be called with no arguments and runtime.lastError will be set to the error message.

setUninstallUrl.name: setUninstallUrl
setUninstallUrl.comment: Sets the URL to be visited upon uninstallation. This may be used to clean up server-side data, do analytics, and implement surveys. Maximum 255 characters.

available.name: available
available.comment:
Returns true if the API is available. The common causes of an API not being avilable are:

  • a permission is missing in the application's manifest.json file
  • the API is defined on a newer version of Chrome then the current runtime

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of chrome/chrome_app.ChromeRuntime.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.
